docs.lead_paragraph: Advancing its campaign to consolidate Blue Cross and Blue Shield companies in the Northeast, Anthem Inc. agreed yesterday to finance a $41 million public health foundation for poor and uninsured people in Connecticut. The agreement settled lawsuits filed by state officials and a coalition of consumer, labor and religious groups after Anthem merged in 1997 with Connecticut Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the state's largest health insurance company.

headline.main: Insurer Establishes Foundation to Settle Lawsuits

docs.abstract: Anthem Inc agrees to finance $41 million public health foundation for poor and uninsured people in Connecticut, advancing campaign to consolidate Blue Cross and Blue Shield companies in Northeast; says extending litigation would not have served state's policyholders or taxpayers and could have affected its reputation and good will; agreement settles lawsuits filed by state officials and coalition of consumer, labor and religious groups after Anthem merged in 1997 with Connecticut Blue Cross and Blue Shield, state's largest health insurance company; Blue Cross-financed foundations, which range from $28 million in Ohio to several billion dollars in California, respond to laws requiring compensation for tax breaks and subsidies given to Blue Cross plans over years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The fight for strong legislation to protect the rights of patients in managed-care health plans has now moved to the House. The House Republican leadership will make a serious mistake if it insists on replicating the Senate's feeble efforts. Americans are plainly worried about managed-care abuses. A number of dissident Republicans have heard these concerns and are pushing for tougher patient protections, including the right to sue health plans when they improperly deny coverage. The issue is whether these Republicans can get their leaders to pay attention. Any meaningful legislation has to cover all 161 million Americans with private health insurance. It should require that appeals of denials of coverage be heard by an independent panel with broad powers of review. The bill should prohibit health plans from dodging this process by defining ''medical necessity'' in unfairly narrow ways. It should also contain a strong enforcement mechanism so that consumers who are injured by wrongful denials of care can get legal redress.

headline.main: One More Chance for Patients' Rights

docs.abstract: Editorial urges House Republican leaders not to block strong bill to protect rights of patients in managed-care health plans

docs.lead_paragraph: With Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley set to address the Rev. Jesse Jackson's coalition of civil rights groups and urban activists next week, Mr. Jackson says he will not endorse either candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination until he sees which seems more effective in championing causes he considers crucial. ''The issue is not who will I endorse,'' Mr. Jackson said in an interview here. ''The issue is whether they will endorse the policies.''

headline.main: With a New Image, Jackson Campaigns Outside 2000 Race

docs.abstract: Rev Jesse Jackson, courted by Vice Pres Al Gore's and Bill Bradley's Presidential campaigns, says he will not endorse either candidate until he sees which candidate seems more effective in championing key causes, interview; political anaylsts say his influence with potential voters has increased in recent years; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Beverly Enterprises, the nation's largest nursing home chain, said today that it would take a second-quarter pretax charge of $175 million to $225 million in anticipation of settling a Medicare fraud investigation. The charge, which could equal Beverly's earnings for the last eight years, indicates the company expects to pay the largest financial penalty ever against a nursing home company for health care fraud.

headline.main: Beverly to Take Big Charge Before Settling Investigation

docs.abstract: Beverly Enterprises, nation's largest nursing home chain, will take second-quarter 1999 pre-tax charge of $175 million to $225 million in anticipation of settling Medicare fraud investigation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Stymied by Republican dissension, House Republican leaders made a tentative decision today to bypass their own committees in an effort to push legislation regulating managed care through the House before the August Congressional recess. Senior Republican aides said that Speaker J. Dennis Hastert was looking to pass a ''modified'' version of legislation that the Senate approved on a near party-line vote earlier this month and that Mr. Hastert and other Republican leaders wanted the bill to hew as closely as possible to a Republican package that squeaked by the House last year on a 216-to-210 vote.

headline.main: House Leaders Try to Stem Dissent Over Managed Care

docs.abstract: House Republican leaders, stymied by Republican dissension, tentatively decide to bypass own committees in effort to push modified version of Senate-approved bill to regulate managed health care through House before Aug recess; favor bill that would extend consumer protections to far more Americans than would Senate bill; are unclear about whether their bill would let patients sue managed care providers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal health officials last week issued model standards for the 300 fertility clinics in the nation, giving states a tool if they choose to start accrediting such clinics. State action is voluntary, but some state legislators have been considering establishing some regulatory framework, especially after incidents like the embryo mix-up at a New York laboratory in which one woman gave birth to twins, one of whom was another couple's genetic child.

headline.main: A New 'to-Do' List for Fertility Clinics

docs.abstract: Federal health officials issue model standards for 300 fertility clinics in nation, giving states a tool if they choose to start accrediting such clinics; guidelines, issued by Health and Human Services Sec Donna E Shalala, are intended to make sure that embryology laboratories and clinics meet standards on laboratory procedures and equipment, record keeping and personnel qualifications (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans will end a risk-sharing arrangement that covered 13,000 members of a Medicare health care plan in New Jersey. Under the agreement, Heritage New Jersey Medical Group PC has provided claims administration and management services for the Oxford Medicare members. Oxford, based in Norwalk, Conn., has been responsible for services like marketing, member enrollment and compliance.

headline.main: Metro Business; Oxford Ends Its Role In a Medicare Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: There were plenty of signs that the contractor putting a new roof on Public School 131 in Brooklyn was botching the job and cutting corners on safety. One worker bore into the old asphalt and tar with a jackhammer right above a classroom, knocking a big chunk of ceiling plaster onto a child's desk. Others sloshed gasoline in the hallways, and water leaking through the roof shorted out lights and ruined walls, disrupting classes and causing an asbestos scare.
docs.abstract: First article in two-part series, Physically Unfit, on school construction in New York City which over over past decade has been marked by turmoil; construction efforts have been hampered by chaotic planning, political competition for classrooms and bureaucratic strife between Board of Education and School Construction Authority--with reliance on careless and inept contractors and failure to police them probably system's two most wasteful and potentially dangerous flaws that may have caused construction-realted death of 16-year-old girl outside Public School 131 in Brooklyn in 1998; focus of School Construction Authority has shifted from building new schools to repairing old ones often while children attend classes, heightening dangers from bad contractors; with old schools filled with asbestos and other hidden hazards, city's biggest and best contractors often avoid such renovations, choosing easier and more profitable jobs in booming private sector; at same time, finding substitute space for thousands of students while buildings are being renovated has proven difficult and children are often forced to coexist in close proximity to work being done by smaller and less experienced contractors, including some who illegally rely on low-paid and unskilled labor; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Donna Allen, an early standard-bearer of feminism who kept an eye on the news and communications industry from her Washington home, died on July 19 of a heart attack. She was 78. Her family said she died at a hospital but declined to identify it.

headline.main: Donna Allen, 78, a Feminist and an Organizer

docs.abstract: Donna Allen, early standard-bearer of feminism who kept an eye on news and communications industry from her Washington home, dies at age 78 (M)
docs.snippet: Donna Allen, an early standard-bearer of feminism who kept an eye on the news and communications industry from her Washington home, died on July 19 of a heart attack. She was 78.    Her family said she died at a hospital but declined to identify it.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration said for the first time today that it would not accept a compromise $500 billion tax-cut plan proposed by a group of Senate Democrats, virtually assuring that the debate over how to spend the projected budget surplus will not be settled quickly or easily. ''The President will veto a $500 billion tax cut because it doesn't leave room for what's necessary,'' said Lawrence H. Summers, the Treasury Secretary.

headline.main: Clinton Says No To Any Tax Cut Of $500 Billion

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration for first time says it will reject compromise $500 billion tax-cut plan proposed by group of Senate Democrats, complicating contentious debate over how to spend projected budget surplus; Treas Sec Lawrence H Summers says President will veto plan since it does not leave room for what is necessary; White House economic adviser Gene Sperling says Clinton will veto tax cut of $800 billion or $500 billion because it threatens ability to secure Medicare and Social Security and pay down national debt; Senate Democrats proposed plan to cut taxes by $500 billion over 10 years to bridge gap between $792 billion cut approved by House of Representatives and $250 billion to $300 billion offered by White House; chart (M)
